1 war correspondent on an Allied ship was killed | notes = | campaignbox = {{Campaignbox Bombing of SE Asia 1944-45}} }} {{Campaignbox South-East Asia}} [[File:Corsair on HMS Glory (R62) off Rabaul 1945.jpg|200px|thumb|right|FAA [[Vought F4U Corsair]]s, the type of airplane used in the aerial attack.]] '''Operation ''Crimson''''' was a [[Royal Navy|British]]-led naval operation in [[World War II]], the objective being simultaneous [[naval bombardment]] and [[aerial strikes]] on [[Japan]]ese airfields in the [[Indonesia]]n cities of [[Sabang, Indonesia|Sabang]], [[Lhoknga]] and [[Banda Aceh|Kutaraja]],Patrick Boniface, HMS ''Cumberland'', page 86, 2006. to be launched from [[aircraft carriers]] in the [[Indian Ocean]] on 25 July 1944. == Plan == Unlike some earlier operations which had used small forces for harassment and diversion of the Japanese, Operation ''Crimson'' was "a full-blooded operation" designed to "make a mess of the air base and harbour installations and wreck any vessels found sheltering there."Malcolm H. Murfett, ''Naval Warfare 1919-45: An Operational History of the Volatile War at Sea'', page 357, 2008. Sailing from [[Trincomalee]], under the command of Admiral [[James Somerville]],Stanley Sandler, ''World War II in the Pacific: An Encyclopedia'', page 729, 2001. were two aircraft carriers ({{HMS|Victorious|R38|6}} and ''[[HMS Illustrious (R87)|Illustrious]]'') with four battleships {{HMS|Queen Elizabeth|1913|6}}, {{HMS|Valiant|1914|6}}, {{HMS|Renown|1916|6}}, and the [[French battleship Richelieu|French battleship ''Richelieu'']], as well as six cruisers ({{HMS|Ceylon|30|2}}, {{HMS|Cumberland|57|2}}, {{HMS|Gambia|48|2}}, {{HMS|Nigeria|60|2}}, {{HMS|Phoebe|43|2}}, ''[[HNLMS Tromp (1937)|Tromp]]''), with ten destroyers ({{HMS|Quality|G62|2}}, ''[[HMAS Quickmatch (G92)|Quickmatch]]'', {{HMS|Quilliam|G09|2}},{{cite web | url=http://www.naval-history.net/xGM-Chrono-10DD-50Q-Quilliam.htm | title=HMS QUILLIAM | work=Naval History | year=2003 | accessdate=19 October 2013 | author=Mason, Geoffrey}} {{HMS|Racehorse|H11|2}}, {{HMS|Raider|H15|2}}, {{HMS|Rapid|H32|2}}, {{HMS|Relentless|H85|2}}, {{HMS|Rocket|H92|2}}, {{HMS|Roebuck|H95|2}}, {{HMS|Rotherham|H09|2}}){{cite web | url=http://www.naval-history.net/xGM-Chrono-10DD-53R-Raider.htm | title=HMS RAIDER | work=Naval History | year=2003 | accessdate=19 October 2013 | author=Mason, Geoffrey}} supported by two submarines (''[[HMS Templar (P316)|Templar]]'', ''[[HMS Tantalus (P318)|Tantalus]]'').{{cite book| last = Hobbs| first = David| title = The British Pacific Fleet: The Royal Navy's Most Powerful Strike Force| publisher = Seaforth Publishing| edition = 2nd| date = 2012| pages = 50–52| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=FGKCAwAAQBAJ&dq=&source=gbs_navlinks_s| isbn = 9781783469222}} == Attack == The aircraft carriers launched 34–39 [[Vought F4U Corsair]] fighters, under Lieutenant Commander Frederick Richard Arnold Turnbull. In spite of a five minute delay, it was too dark for the planes to accurately strafe the air fields, so instead they attacked large buildings within the vicinity. Japanese AA defences shot down a single Corsair, though the pilot was rescued. The battleships, aided by aircraft from ''Illustrious'', bombarded Sabang harbour installations and the local barracks from afar. The cruisers attacked shore batteries and a wireless station, while the destroyers focused on a radar station. Following the main bombardment, ''Tromp'', ''Quality'', ''Quickmatch'', and ''Quilliam'' under Captain [[Richard Onslow (Royal Navy officer)|Richard Onslow]] entered the harbor at Sabang and shelled Japanese positions.{{cite web | url=http://pacific.valka.cz/forces/rn.htm#bishop | title="BISHOP" - BEIF Covering operation for Rangoon Landing | work=Royal Navy in Pacific and Indian Oceans area | accessdate=19 October 2013}}[http://pacific.valka.cz/forces/rn.htm#bishop Table of actions by Royal Navy]. [[Coastal artillery]] damaged all but the ''Quickmatch'', causing some casualties and killing a war correspondent. As the task force withdrew, two Japanese aircraft tried to shadow, but both were intercepted and shot down. Later in the afternoon, 9–10 [[Mitsubishi A6M Zero|A6M "Zero"]] fighters engaged 13 Corsairs. The British destroyed two fighters and damaged two more. == Aftermath == The Allies lost a total of two Corsairs during the operation. A report of the raid states: {{quotation|The force arrived at flying off position in the early hours of Tuesday 25 July and at 4am the capital ships were detached to bombard Sambang along with Cumberland, Kenya and Nigeria. At 5.25am the two carriers launched their aircraft. The raid was a success with a great deal of damage done to the Japanese forces.}} Operation ''Crimson'' was the final event of Admiral Somerville's military command before concerns about his health forced his transfer to diplomatic duty. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://pacific.valka.cz/forces/rn.htm#sabang Table of actions by Royal Navy] {{coord missing}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Crimson, Operation}} [[Category:World War II operations and battles of the Southeast Asia Theatre]] [[Category:Naval aviation operations and battles]] [[Category:Naval battles of World War II involving the Netherlands]] [[Category:Naval battles of World War II involving France]] [[Category:Aerial operations and battles of World War II involving the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Naval battles and operations of World War II involving the United Kingdom]]
